newsitem.title: POLAND: Shy Polish poet happy, nervous over Nobel prize.
newsitem.headline: Shy Polish poet happy, nervous over Nobel prize.

text.p: Polish poet Wislawa Szymborska, shy winner of this year's Nobel Literature Prize, said on Thursday she was very pleased but also apprehensive at the prospect of intense worldwide attention.

"This is a difficult situation. I am normally a very private person and now I forsee some difficult moments," Szymborska, 73, laughing with excitement, said by telephone from a hotel for writers in the mountain resort of Zakopane.
"I am very pleased for Polish literature although there are other poets like me in Poland...Tadeusz Rozewicz and Zbigniew Herbert to mention only two," Szymborska told Reuters.
She said that although she had been named among the candidates, her selection by the Swedish academy -- which carries a $1.12 million award -- had come as a surprise.
Szymborska paid warm tribute to Anders Bodegard, Swedish translator of her poems, which the academy recognised were hard to put into other languages due to their stylistic variety.
"If this had been a mediocre translator we would not be talking today," she said, herself a translator of French poetry.
Asked whether she would appear more in public and perhaps give lectures abroad, the slight, grey-haired poet said she did not yet know, but commented: "No, I never give lectures."
Earlier this week Szymborska won the Polish PEN Club's poetry award and Polish literary critics were overjoyed at the Nobel literature award, the fourth to go to a Pole.
"We could not believe it at first. She was a candidate we put forward many times," Jacek Bochenski, the Club's deputy president, told Reuters, calling the news wonderful.
"Her poetry is profound, beautiful, full of humour, simple. It easily finds its way to the reader, it is universal," he said.
"She is the best Polish post-war woman poet," literary critic Tadeusz Nyczek told Zycie newspaper, which had speculated earlier on Thursday that Szymborska might win.
Respected Polish novelist Stanislaw Lem, who like Szymborska lives in the southern city of Krakow, told PAP news agency: "Wiska (Wieslawa) simply deserved this prize."
The high-brow science fiction author pointed out that poet Czeslaw Milosz had won the 1980 literature prize, adding that this showed Poland's poetry was greater than its prose.
Milosz, who lives in the United States, told RMF-FM radio he was glad, as he was a great admirer of Szymborska's work.
"Above all, this is a great triumph of Polish 20th century poetry," he said.
Earlier Polish winners are novelists Henryk Sienkiewicz in 1905 and Wladyslaw Reymont in 1924.

The award to Szymborska surprised international observers, who had expected a novelist to win this year after Irish poet Seamus Heaney, who was due to begin a visit to Krakow on Thursday, took last year's prize.
The Swedish academy said Szymborska won for "poetry that with ironic precision allows the historical and biological context to come to light in fragments of human reality."

Szymborska, also a literary critic, has published several slim volumes of poetry since Stalinist censorship was lifted in 1957 -- she has disowned earlier poems which reflected Stalinist era literary style and content.
Her poetry includes "Calling out to the Yeti" (1957) and "People on the Bridge" (1986), and "The End and the Beginning" written in 1993.
